item.title: Spiritual Theology - Chapter 11
item.description:
This episode delves into Father Jordan Aumann's Chapter 11 of Spiritual Theology, focusing on the moral virtues as essential means for attaining a supernatural end. Unlike theological virtues that directly orient us to God, moral virtues rectify our faculties and actions for that end. The discussion centers on the four cardinal virtues: prudence, justice, temperance, and fortitude, and their corresponding gifts of the Holy Spirit.

Prudence, defined as "right reason in action", is considered the most necessary virtue, guiding us in applying other virtues correctly. It involves three acts: deliberation, judgment, and execution. Its perfection comes through the gift of counsel, a supernatural impulse from the Holy Spirit that transcends human reason.

Justice is presented as the foundation of true peace, defined as rendering to each what is strictly due. Aumann categorizes justice into legal, distributive, and commutative. The virtue of religion, which gives God His due worship, and piety, which honors parents and country, are key annexed virtues. Justice is perfected by the gift of piety, fostering a filial love for God and a universal kinship with all people.

Temperance moderates sense pleasures, particularly taste and touch. Infused temperance, enlightened by faith, aims for supernatural perfection beyond mere bodily control. Humility is highlighted as a fundamental related virtue, grounded in the truth that all good comes from God and the justice of giving Him glory. Temperance is perfected by the gift of fear of the Lord, which is a filial reverence for God that leads to avoiding anything that would offend Him.

Finally, Fortitude strengthens the will to pursue good amidst danger, with its principal act being endurance. Magnanimity and patience are annexed virtues, enabling great acts and bearing suffering with a tranquil spirit. The gift of fortitude perfects this virtue, providing invincible confidence and supernatural energy for heroism, even in mundane daily duties. These virtues, infused by God and perfected by His gifts, prepare individuals for ultimate union with God.

item.title: Spiritual Theology - Chapter 13
item.description:
This episode of "The Workshop" delves into Chapter 13 of Father Jordan Aumann's Spiritual Theology, titled "Aids to Spiritual Growth." Having established the doctrinal foundations of the spiritual life, this chapter provides the practical tools for cultivating union with God and perfecting charity. These aids are presented not as isolated practices, but as integrated means to cooperate with grace daily.

The first aid discussed is the practice of the presence of God, which involves consciously recognizing God's active presence. Aumann outlines five types: immensity (God's presence in all creation), indwelling (God dwelling in the soul through grace as friend and Father), sacramental (Christ in the Eucharist), personal/hypostatic (Christ's humanity united to the Word), and manifestation (heaven). For practical spiritual growth, immensity and indwelling are key, transforming one's moral vision and impelling perfection.

Next is the Examination of Conscience, presented not merely as an accounting of sins, but as a vital spiritual exercise. Aumann distinguishes between the general examen (a broad daily review) and the more focused particular examen, which targets specific faults or virtues. This strategic approach moves from merely cataloging symptoms to diagnosing underlying dispositions, fostering true self-knowledge.

The Desire for Perfection is a crucial psychological factor, defined as a determined act of the will aspiring unceasingly to sanctity. Aumann, citing St. Thomas Aquinas ("Will it.") and St. Teresa of Avila, outlines its essential qualities: it must be supernatural, humble, confident, predominant, constant, and practical.

Conformity to the will of God is presented as a highly efficacious means of sanctification, the very essence of charity in action. Aumann distinguishes God's will of expression (commands) from His will of good pleasure (providential dispositions), with the latter requiring "holy abandonment" or "holy indifference"—a loving submission to all circumstances, trusting God's wisdom even in adversity.

Fidelity to Grace is the fifth aid, our moment-to-moment cooperation with divine inspirations. Aumann emphasizes that infidelity can impede subsequent graces. Discernment is crucial, with signs of divine inspiration including peace, humility, docility, and conformity to faith. Cardinal Mercier's prayer, "O Holy Spirit, soul of my soul...", encapsulates this disposition.

Additional aids include a structured Plan of Life, adapted to one's state; Spiritual Reading, aimed at piety and stirring love; and Holy Friendships, which can be sources of support but require discernment to avoid disordered attachments. Finally, Spiritual Direction is highlighted as a comprehensive aid. While not strictly necessary for salvation, it's morally essential for spiritual growth, applying theological principles to individual journeys. A good director must be learned, prudent, and experienced, while the directed soul must exhibit sincerity, obedience, and perseverance, ultimately growing in docility to the Holy Spirit, the true interior guide.

item.title: Spiritual Theology - Chapter 14
item.description:
This episode of "The Workshop" delves into Chapter 14 of Jordan Aumann's Spiritual Theology, focusing on "Discernment of Spirits." This chapter provides a crucial framework for analyzing extraordinary spiritual experiences—impulses, visions, emotions, or revelations—to determine their source: the divine, diabolical, or human spirit. Aumann emphasizes that discernment is an "acquired art" essential for spiritual direction, as the spiritual well-being of a soul is at stake.

Aumann establishes a foundational framework of three potential sources: the divine spirit, which always inclines to good; the diabolical spirit, which always inclines to evil; and the human spirit, wounded by sin, which can incline to either. He notes that these spirits can intermingle, so the task is to identify the predominant spirit driving an experience. Signs of the Divine Spirit include truth (consistency with revealed truth and Church teaching), docility, humility (a profound recognition of one's nothingness), and a deep, stable peace. In contrast, signs of the diabolical spirit are often inversions: falsity (using half-truths), obstinacy, and initial sweetness followed by confusion, anxiety, and depression. Aumann distinguishes between diabolical obsession (external torment) and rarer possession (devil invading the body), noting that even in possession, the soul's intellect and will remain free. The human spirit is characterized by self-love and egoism, often difficult to distinguish from diabolical influence but distinct from the clear, humble peace of God.

Aumann's core methodology for analyzing phenomena is a principle of theological caution: "one may not definitely attribute to a supernatural cause that which could possibly have a natural (or diabolical) explanation." This "theological Occam's Razor" requires exhausting all natural explanations first. He explores physiological and constitutional factors (e.g., how melancholic or sanguine temperaments might influence experiences) and the role of the imagination. The imagination can only recall and rearrange existing images, meaning phenomena like spontaneously speaking an unknown language cannot be its product, indicating a supernatural or preternatural cause. While the devil can produce imaginative visions, falsify ecstatic states, or cause physical marks like stigmata (with God's permission), he cannot work true miracles, know future contingencies with certainty, or directly access the intellect and will. This limitation makes a true intellectual vision a sure sign of a divine source.

Aumann distinguishes between gratiae gratis datae (charisms), which are graces for the benefit of others (like prophecy or tongues) and do not require a state of grace, and concomitant mystical phenomena, which are normal manifestations of the mystical state itself (like intuitive knowledge of God's presence or spiritual joy) flowing from the gifts of the Holy Spirit. He then systematically catalogs specific extraordinary phenomena, including visions (corporeal, imaginative, and intellectual—with intellectual being the safest due to direct action on the intellect) and locutions (auricular, imaginative, and intellectual, with substantial intellectual locutions being the most powerful and certain, immediately effecting what is said in the soul). For phenomena like stigmata, Aumann is cautious, acknowledging psychological explanations but providing criteria for authenticity (e.g., bleeding on Passion days, purity of blood, resistance to medical healing). For bilocation, he philosophically explains it as apparent presence via divine or angelic representation rather than a physical body in two places. For every phenomenon, he applies this methodical rigor: first ruling out natural causes, then diabolical, and finally looking for the positive signs of the divine spirit, with the ultimate litmus test being the spiritual fruit (e.g., profound charity, deeper humility, heroic patience) it bears in the soul's virtue.
